Benfica|access-date=12 July 2017}}}} == Records and statistics == {{Further||List of S.L. Benfica records and statistics|S.L. Benfica in European football#Records}} === Individual === [[File:EusebioSLB.jpg|thumb|200px|Statue of Benfica's all-time top scorer, [[Eusébio]] (473 goals)]] [[Nené (footballer, born 1949)|Nené]] is the Benfica player with most official appearances (575).{{cite news|last=Rebelo|first=Marco|date=12 August 2016|title=No reino dos maiores|trans-title=In the realm of the greatest|work=O Benfica|language=pt|issue=3772|publisher=S.L. Benfica|page=8|issn=1073-0311}} Eusébio is the club's all-time top goalscorer,{{cite web|url=http://www.worldsoccer.com/columnists/keir-radnedge/eusebio-344295|title=Portugal legend Eusebio remembered|last=Rainbow|first=Jamie|date=6 January 2014|website=[[World Soccer (magazine)|World Soccer]]|access-date=12 June 2016}} with 473 goals in 440 competitive matches.{{cite web|url=http://newafricanmagazine.com/the-great-eusébio/|title=The great Eusébio|date=28 January 2014|work=[[New African]]|access-date=12 June 2016}} He is also Benfica's top scorer in UEFA club competitions, with 56 goals. [[Luisão]] is the player with most trophies won (20), the captain with most matches and has the most appearances in European matches.{{cite news|last=Bragança|first=José|date=28 April 2015|title=Luisão, um capitão para a história|trans-title=Luisão, a captain for the ages|url=https://www.zerozero.pt/noticia.php?id=154221|language=pt|work=zerozero|access-date=28 April 2015}} Cosme Damião is the longest-serving coach (18 consecutive years).{{cite web|url=https://www.zerozero.pt/text.php?id=11474|title=Cosme Damião: o fundador|last=Silveira|first=João Pedro|date=30 June 2015|website=zerozero|language=pt|trans-title=Cosme Damião: the founder|access-date=18 June 2016}} Otto Glória is the coach with the most league titles won (4).{{cite news|date=18 May 2015|title=O "bi" inédito, o "top" português e as outras marcas de JJ|trans-title=The unprecedented "bi", the Portuguese top and other JJ's records|url=https://maisfutebol.iol.pt/historico/benfica/o-bi-inedito-o-top-portugues-e-as-outras-marcas-de-jj|language=pt|work=Maisfutebol|access-date=7 January 2016}} Jorge Jesus is the coach with most trophies won (10: 3 leagues, 1 cup, 5 league cups, 1 super cup).{{cite news|date=29 June 2015|title=Jesus soma 10 títulos e chega a número 1 dos treinadores do Benfica|trans-title=Jesus accounts for 10 titles and is Benfica's most decorated coach|url=https://www.jn.pt/PaginaInicial/Desporto/Interior.aspx?content_id=4597483|language=pt|work=[[Jornal de Notícias]]|access-date=26 January 2016}} Rui Vitória is the coach with the highest percentage of wins in the domestic league with a minimum 34 matches played (85.29%).{{cite news|last1=Brites Dias|first1=Andreia|last2=Sousa|first2=Vasco|date=15 May 2016|title=Rui Vitória: o treinador encarnado com maior percentagem de vitórias|trans-title=Rui Vitória: the Benfica coach with the highest percentage of wins|url=https://www.zerozero.pt/news.php?id=174914|language=pt|work=zerozero|access-date=17 May 2016}} === Team === Benfica became the first team in Portuguese league history to complete two seasons without defeat, namely the 1972–73 and [[1977–78 Primeira Divisão|1977–78]]{{sfn|Pereira|2009|p=110}} seasons. In the former, as unbeaten champions, they achieved two records: 58 points in 30 matches, the most ever obtained (96.7% efficiency), and the largest difference of points ever between champions and runners-up (18 points) in a two-points-per-win system.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/unbeaten.html#season|title=Unbeaten during a League Season|last=Stokkermans|first=Karel|date=23 December 2013|website=RSSSF|access-date=1 January 2014}} In the 2015–16 campaign, Benfica amassed 88 points in 34 matches and set the points record since the league is contested by 18 teams.{{cite news|date=15 May 2016|title=Benfica wrap up Portuguese league title with victory over Nacional|url=http://www.espnfc.com/benfica/story/2873689/benfica-wrap-up-portuguese-league-title-with-nacional-victory|work=ESPN FC|access-date=17 May 2016}} Benfica's record of lowest number of goals conceded in the Primeira Liga was achieved in 1988–89 with manager [[António José Conceição Oliveira|Toni]]: 15 goals in 38 matches. Furthermore, Benfica hold the European record for the [[European association football club records#Most consecutive wins in domestic league|most consecutive wins in domestic league]] (29), between 1971–72 and 1972–73,{{cite news|date=14 January 2017|title=Europe's longest domestic winning streaks|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=2406769.html|work=UEFA|access-date=20 January 2017}} as well as the domestic record for the longest unbeaten run in the league (56 matches), from 24 October 1976 to 1 September 1978.{{sfn|Pereira|2009|p=106}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/unb-benfica-56.html|title=SL Benfica's series of 56 matches unbeaten in the I Divisão|last=Martins|first=Paulo|date=27 July 2004|website=RSSSF|access-date=1 January 2014}} In addition, Benfica hold Europe's longest unbeaten run in all competitions since the advent of European competition: 48 matches from December 1963 to 14 February 1965. This record ranks third overall.{{cite news|date=15 January 2017|title=Europe's longest unbeaten runs in all competitions|url=https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=2435340.html|work=UEFA|access-date=20 January 2017}} In the [[1965–66 European Cup]], Benfica scored 18 goals against [[Stade Dudelange]] and achieved the [[European association football club records#Highest goal margin (aggregate) in European Cup|highest goal margin on aggregate in European Cup]]{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/ecc.html#rec|title=Champions' Cup/Champions League Trivia|last=Stokkermans|first=Karel|date=30 April 2015|website=RSSSF|access-date=17 June 2016}} and their biggest win in UEFA competitions. In the UEFA Europa League, Benfica was the first club to reach two finals consecutively, the [[2013–14 UEFA Europa League|latter]] without defeat.{{cite news|date=14 May 2014|title=Benfica é rei sem coroa da competição|trans-title=Benfica is the competition's crownless king|url=https://www.record.pt/internacional/competicoes-de-clubes/liga-europa/detalhe/benfica-e-rei-sem-coroa-da-competicao-883200|language=pt|work=Record|access-date=22 December 2015}} As of the 2017–18 season, Benfica have 37 appearances in the European Cup/UEFA Champions League and 19 appearances in the UEFA Cup/Europa League. Additionally, they have appearances in now-defunct competitions: 7 in [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] and 2 in the [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]]. === Recent seasons === {{Further|List of S.L. Benfica seasons}} Benfica's season-by-season performance over the last ten (completed) seasons: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Benfica honours}} [[File:Benfica European cups in Museu Cosme Damião (cropped).JPG|thumb|250px|Benfica's two [[European Cup]]s at [[Museu Benfica|Museu Benfica – Cosme Damião]]]] Benfica have won a record 36 Primeira Liga,{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/kamprec.html#tnc|title=Trivia on Winning Domestic Championships|last=Stokkermans|first=Karel|date=14 January 2016|website=RSSSF|access-date=17 January 2016}} a record 26 Taça de Portugal (and 4 consecutively),{{cite web|url=https://www.fpf.pt/pt/Competi%C3%A7%C3%B5es/Futebol-Masculino/Ta%C3%A7a-de-Portugal-Placard/Vencedores|title=Taça de Portugal Placard - Vencedores|website=[[Portuguese Football Federation|FPF]]|trans-title=Taça de Portugal Placard - Winners|language=pt|access-date=5 March 2017}} a record 7 Taça da Liga (and 4 consecutively), 7 Supertaça Cândido de Oliveira and 3 Campeonato de Portugal (and 2 consecutively) – totalling 79 domestic trophies – and 2 European Cups (consecutively won) – totalling 81 trophies, or 82 including the Latin Cup. Therefore, in terms of overall trophies, Benfica is the most decorated club in Portuguese football.{{cite news|date=11 August 2017|title=Hegemonia!|trans-title=Hegemony!|work=O Benfica|language=pt|issue=3824|publisher=S.L. Benfica|at=Back page|issn=1073-0311}} (The Latin Cup, a forerunner of the European Cup,{{cite news|date=4 February 2011|title=Goals, not coal, for Kopa|url=https://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=1590586.html|work=UEFA|access-date=26 September 2016|quote=a forerunner of the European Champion Clubs' Cup}} is excluded from the trophy count by [[FIFA]], although its official website did include it.){{cite news|date=3 February 2006|title=Benfica rediscover past glories|url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=107/edition=248388/news/newsid=102682.html|dead-url=yes|work=FIFA|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525014739/http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=107/edition=248388/news/newsid=102682.html|archive-date=25 May 2011|access-date=23 May 2016}} In 2014, Benfica achieved the first ever treble of Primeira Liga, Taça de Portugal and Taça da Liga.{{cite news|date=18 May 2014|title=Benfica lift cup to seal historic treble|url=https://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/association=por/news/newsid=2107634.html|work=UEFA|access-date=3 July 2015}}{{cite news|date=18 May 2014|title=Benfica conquista Taça e consegue o triplete em Portugal|trans-title=Benfica conquer Portuguese Cup and achieve the treble in Portugal|url=http://pt.fifa.com/world-match-centre/news/newsid/234/083/7/|dead-url=yes|language=pt|work=FIFA|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140519023449/http://pt.fifa.com/world-match-centre/news/newsid/234/083/7/|archive-date=19 May 2014|access-date=18 May 2014}} As of the 2017–18 season, Benfica is the only club to have won the Primeira Liga and Taça da Liga double, moreover, four times. Benfica is also the only club in Portugal to have successfully defended every major domestic title (Campeonato de Portugal, Primeira Liga, Taça de Portugal, Supertaça Cândido de Oliveira and Taça da Liga). In addition, Benfica are the only Portuguese team to have become back-to-back European champions. === Domestic competitions === * '''[[Primeira Liga]]''' : '''Winners (36) – record:''' [[1935–36 Primeira Liga|1935–36]], [[1936–37 Primeira Liga|1936–37]], [[1937–38 Primeira Liga|1937–38]], [[1941–42 Primeira Divisão|1941–42]], [[1942–43 Primeira Divisão|1942–43]], [[1944–45 Primeira Divisão|1944–45]], [[1949–50 Primeira Divisão|1949–50]], [[1954–55 Primeira Divisão|1954–55]], [[1956–57 Primeira Divisão|1956–57]], [[1959–60 Primeira Divisão|1959–60]], [[1960–61 Primeira Divisão|1960–61]], [[1962–63 Primeira Divisão|1962–63]], [[1963–64 Primeira Divisão|1963–64]], [[1964–65 Primeira Divisão|1964–65]], [[1966–67 Primeira Divisão|1966–67]], [[1967–68 Primeira Divisão|1983–84]], [[1986–87 Primeira Divisão|1986–87]], [[1988–89 Primeira Divisão|1988–89]], [[1990–91 Primeira Divisão|1990–91]], [[1993–94 Primeira Divisão|1993–94]], [[2004–05 Primeira '''[[Taça de Portugal]]''' : '''Winners (26) – record:''' [[1939–40 Taça de Portugal|1939–40]], [[1942–43 Taça de Portugal|1942–43]], [[1943–44 Taça de Portugal|1943–44]], [[1949 Taça de Portugal Final|1948–49]], [[1951 Taça de Portugal Final|1950–51]], [[1952 Taça de Portugal Final|1951–52]], [[1953 Taça de Portugal Final|1952–53]], [[1955 Taça de Portugal Final|1954–55]], [[1957 Taça de Portugal Final|1956–57]], [[1959 Taça de Portugal Final|1958–59]], [[1962 Taça de Portugal Final|1961–62]], [[1963–64 Taça de Portugal|1963–64]], [[1968–69 Taça de Portugal|1968–69]], [[1970 Taça de de Portugal Final|1984–85]], [[1986 Taça de Portugal Final|1985–86]], [[1987 Taça de Portugal Final|1986–87]], [[1992–93 Taça de Portugal|1992–93]], [[1995–96 Taça de Portugal|1995–96]], [[2003–04 Taça de Portugal|2003–04]], [[2013–14 Taça de Portugal|2013–14]], [[2016–17 Taça de Portugal|2016–17]] * '''[[Taça da Liga]]''' : '''Winners (7) – record:''' [[2008–09 Taça da Liga|2008–09]], [[2009–10 Taça da Liga|2009–10]], [[2010–11 Taça da Liga|2010–11]], [[2011–12 Taça da Liga|2011–12]], [[2013–14 Taça da Liga|2013–14]], [[2014–15 Taça da Liga|2014–15]], [[2015–16 Taça da Liga|2015–16]] * '''[[Supertaça Cândido de Oliveira]]''' : '''Winners (7):''' [[1980 Supertaça de Portugal|1980]], [[1985 Supertaça Cândido de Oliveira|1985]], [[1989 Supertaça Cândido de Benfica season|1971–72]], [[1980–81 S.L. Benfica season|1980–81]], [[1982–83 S.L. Benfica season|1982–83]], [[1986–87 S.L. Benfica season|1986–87]], [[2013–14 S.L. revision.text:
{{Infobox ski area |name=Solitude Mountain Resort |logo = |image = Solitude-02-2006.jpg |caption = Solitude's lower terrain in 2006 |location = [[Big Cottonwood Canyon]], [[Salt Lake County, Utah|Salt Lake County]], [[Utah]],
{{USA}} |nearest_city = [[Salt Lake City, Utah]] | pushpin_map = Utah |coordinates = {{coord|40|36|54.5|N|111|35|20.1|W|type:landmark_scale:50000|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_label_position = right | map_caption = Location of Solitude Mountain Resort,
southeast of [[Salt Lake City, Utah]] |vertical = {{convert|2047|ft|m|abbr=on}} |top_elevation = {{convert|10035|ft|m|abbr=on}} |base_elevation = {{convert|7988|ft|m|abbr=on}} |skiable_area = {{convert|1200|acre|km2}} |number_trails = 77 |longest_run = {{convert|3.5|mi|km}}
''Honeycomb Trail'' |liftsystem = 8 [[chairlift]]s |snowfall = {{convert|500|in|cm}} |snowmaking = yes |nightskiing = no |external_link = [http://skisolitude.com Ski Solitude.com] |}} '''Solitude Mountain Resort''' is a [[ski resort]] located in the [[Big Cottonwood Canyon]] of the [[Wasatch Range|Wasatch Mountains]], thirty miles southeast of [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]. With 66 trails,http://www.skisolitude.com/community/ {{convert|1200|acre|km2}} and {{convert|2047|ft|m}} vertical, Solitude is one of the smaller ski resorts near Salt Lake City, along with its neighbor [[Brighton Ski Resort|Brighton]]. It is a family-oriented mountain, with a wider range of beginner and intermediate slopes than other nearby ski resorts; 50% of its slopes are graded "beginner" or "intermediate," the highest such ratio in the Salt Lake City area. Solitude was one of the first major US resorts to adopt an [[RFID]] lift ticket system, allowing lift lines to move more efficiently while reducing "lift poaching". It was followed by [[Alta Ski Area]] in 2007. Solitude is adjacent to [[Brighton Ski Resort]] near the top of Big Cottonwood Canyon. Solitude and Brighton offer a common "Solbright Pass" which provides access to both resorts for a nominal surcharge.{{cite web|url=http://www.skisolitude.com/winter/day_pass.php |title=Day Tickets – Winter – Salt Lake City, Utah Ski Resort |publisher=www.skisolitude.com |accessdate=2009-01-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090101093913/http://www.skisolitude.com/winter/day_pass.php |archivedate=January 1, 2009 }} ==The Mountain== Most of Solitude's [[trail]]s descend from a [[ridge]] (Eagle Ridge trail) which runs parallel with [[Utah State Route 190|The Big Cottonwood Canyon Scenic Byway]] as it rises up the center of Big Cottonwood Canyon. Two [[ski lifts|lifts]]—quad chairs Powder Horn II and Eagle Express—run to the top of Eagle Ridge, while quads Apex Express and Moonbeam Express feed the intermediate and beginner terrain (respectively) immediately below it. The back of Eagle Ridge drops into Honeycomb Canyon, a long [[valley]] with most of the resort's [[bowl skiing]]. Honeycomb Canyon is primarily accessed by the Summit Express Chair lift, which runs behind Eagle Ridge to the mountain's summit; return access from the bottom of Honeycomb Canyon is also available via the Honeycomb Return quad. The Summit Chair also provides access to adjacent [[Brighton Ski Resort]]. Two more lifts, Link double and Sunrise triple, provide dedicated skiing areas for beginners. ==History== Solitude was first developed for skiing by [[Moab, Utah]], [[uranium]] [[tycoon]] Robert M. Barrett. Barrett decided to start his own ski resort after being denied the use of the restrooms at [[Alta Ski Resort|Alta]], which were reserved for Alta guests only.{{cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4188/is_20050210/ai_n11502746/pg_1|title=Ski resort of the week: Solitude|work= Deseret News (Salt Lake City)|via=findarticles.com|accessdate=2009-02-05|date=2005-02-10|last=Grass|first=Ray}} He started construction at Solitude in 1956, having bought all the land in [[Big Cottonwood Canyon]], the next canyon over from Alta.{{cite web|url=http://www.skisolitude.com/home/history.cfm |title=History – Salt Lake City, Utah Ski Resort |publisher=www.skisolitude.com |accessdate=2009-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725041250/http://www.skisolitude.com/home/history.cfm |archivedate=July 25, 2008 }} The resort opened for business one year later, and passed through ownership changes until it was acquired by a business group led by Gary DeSeelhorst in 1977.{{cite web|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/north-america/united-states-utah/271881-1.html|title=Moguls behind the moguls: Utah's ski resort owners.|publisher=www.allbusiness.com|accessdate=2009-02-05|date=1991-12-01|last=Horowitz|first=Alan}} DeSeelhorst became the resort's sole owner in 1986 and implemented an aggressive renovation project, including the 1989 construction of Utah's first express quad chairlift, Eagle Express. Accommodations upgrades in this period included the construction of the Creekside lodge in 1995. On October 3, 2014, [[Deer Valley|Deer Valley Resort]] announced that they had entered into an agreement to buy Solitude from the DeSeelhorst family and took over operation of the resort on May 1, 2015.http://blog.deervalley.com/skiing/deer-valley-resorts-purchase-of-solitude-mountain-resort-official During the summer of 2015 under the new leadership of Deer Valley Resort, the existing Summit double chair was replaced with a new high speed detachable quad with a new alignment. The new lift combined with a new access trail from the top of the Apex Express lift will significantly decrease the travel time to Honeycomb Canyon.{{Cite web |url=http://www.snocountry.com/en/news/entry/new-summit-quad-new-run-more-on-tap-as-deer-valley-officially-takes-over-solitude-operations |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-12-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208125453/http://www.snocountry.com/en/news/entry/new-summit-quad-new-run-more-on-tap-as-deer-valley-officially-takes-over-solitude-operations |archive-date=2015-12-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In August 2017, parent resort Deer Valley was acquired by the new multi-resort entity called [[Alterra Mountain Company]].{{Cite web|url=http://blog.deervalley.com/deer-valley-resort-to-be-acquired-by-newly-formed-resort-company-and-joined-with-intrawest-mammoth-resorts-and-squaw-valley-ski-holdings/|title=Deer Valley Resort to be Acquired by Newly Formed Resort Company and Joined with Intrawest, Mammoth Resorts, and Squaw Valley Ski Holdings {{!}} The Official Blog of Deer Valley Resort|website=blog.deervalley.com|access-date=2017-08-21}} Solitude continued to be owned by the former Deer Valley ownership for one more season until it was announced on June 20, 2018 that Solitude had agreed to be sold to Alterra. {{cite web |url=https://www.alterramtnco.com/news/2018/06/20/solitude-acquisition |title=ALTERRA MOUNTAIN COMPANY TO ACQUIRE SOLITUDE MOUNTAIN RESORT IN UTAH |work=Alterra Mountain Co |date=June 20, 2018}} Solitude is the host for the snowboardcross and ski cross events for the [[FIS Freestyle Ski and Snowboarding World Championships 2019]].{{Cite web|url=https://2019worldchamps.com/venues/|title=Venues|website=FIS World Championships February 1-10, 2019 snowboard {{!}} freestyle freeski|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-29}} ==Solitude Nordic Center== Solitude Resort also operates a nordic center. The Solitude Nordic Center, nestled between the Solitude and Brighton ski areas, offers a variety of [[nordic skiing|nordic]] sport opportunities, including [[snowshoe]]ing, [[Cross-country skiing#Free.2FSkating|skate]] and [[Cross-country skiing#Classic|classic cross-country skiing]]. The site's 13 cross-country skiing trails cover twelve miles (almost 20 km) evenly divided between "easiest" and "moderately difficult", including a long loop of two miles (3 km). Six snowshoe trails cover six miles (ten kilometers). Instruction and training workshops are offered. ==Facts and figures== *Base elevation: {{convert|7988|ft|m}} *Summit elevation: {{convert|10035|ft|m}} *Vertical rise: {{convert|2047|ft|m}} *Total skiable area: {{convert|1200|acre|km2}} *Lifts: 8 [[chairlift]]s: (4 [[detachable chairlift|detachable quad]], 2 fixed-grip quad, 1 triple, 1 double) *Runs: **Beginner: 10% (Green Circle) **Intermediate: 40% (Blue Square-more difficult) **Advanced/Expert: 50% (Black Diamond-most difficult) Named a Top 20 Family Ski Resort for two consecutive years, 2007-2008http://www.familyskiresorts.net {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314130455/http://www.familyskiresorts.net/ |date=2009-03-14 }} ==Chairlifts== *Moonbeam Express *Apex Express *Eagle Express *Summit Express *Powderhorn Chair *Honeycomb Chair *Link Chair *Sunrise Chair ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.skisolitude.com Solitude Mountain Resort Official Site] [[Category:Sports venues in Salt Lake County, Utah]] [[Category:Ski areas and resorts in Utah]] [[Category:Radio-frequency identification]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1957]] [[Category:Wasatch Range]]

revision.comment: correct one field in a citation
revision.text:
{{other uses|Sporting Life (disambiguation){{!}}Sporting Life}} {{Infobox magazine |title = Sporting Life |image_file =Sporting Life, September 10, 1910 - "Electric Light Ball".pdf |image_size =175 |image_caption =Front page on September 10, 1910, announcing the arrival of "Electric Light Ball" |editor = [[Francis Richter]] |editor_title = |previous_editor = |staff_writer = |frequency = Weekly (1883-1917, 1922-1924) |total_circulation = | circulation_year = |category = Sports |company = |publisher = |firstdate = 1883 |country = [[United States]] |based = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] |language = |website = |issn = }} The '''''Sporting Life''''' was an American weekly newspaper, published from 1883 to 1917 and from 1922 to 1924,<ref>{{cite book|author=Dean Hanley and Allyson Hamlin|title=Before There Was Bubble Gum: Our Favorite Pre-World War I Baseball Cards|publisher=Dean's Cards|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p56bPjaeFp0C&pg=PT46&dq=%22sporting+life%22+1924+1883&hl=en&sa=X&ei=B2DyT4_LGaOq2gWB7rjwAQ&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22sporting%20life%22%201924%201883&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Honus Wagner W600 Cabinet Baseball Card|publisher=Dean's Cards|date=November 16, 2010|url=http://blog.deanscards.com/2010/11/honus-wagner-w600-cabinet-baseball-card.html}}(1883-1917 and 1922-1924)</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Case Studies|publisher=InfoVance|url=http://www.infovanceinc.com/pages/casestudy.html}}(1883-1924)</ref> that provided national coverage on sports with a particular focus on [[baseball]] and [[trap shooting]]. The masthead on the front page of newspaper displayed the motto (shown in image at right): "Devoted To Base Ball, Trap Shooting and General Sports."<ref>{{cite news|title=Front page|newspaper=Sporting Life|date=September 10, 1910}}</ref><ref name=BF/> It was founded in Philadelphia in 1883 by [[Francis Richter]], Thomas Sotesbury Dando, and August Rudolph. Richter was the newspaper's publisher until 1917. He hired correspondents to report from locales across the United States and continued to publish and edit the ''Sporting Life'' until 1917.<ref>{{cite news|title=Obituary of Francis C. Richter|newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer|date=February 13, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Amber Shaw|title=The Impact of Francis Richter on the Development of Baseball|publisher=The University of Georgia's Journal for Undergraduate Research Opportunities|year=2003|url=http://juro.uga.edu/2003/shaw.htm}}</ref> Throughout most of its existence, it was in competition with ''[[The Sporting News]]'', which was founded in 1886 and published by the Spink brothers in St. Louis. By 1890, it had "the largest circulation of any sporting or baseball newspaper" in the United States.<ref name=BF>{{cite web|author=Bill Burgess|title=The Sporting Life|publisher=Baseball-Fever.com|date=June 25, 2009|url=http://www.baseball-fever.com/showthread.php?91319-The-Sporting-Life}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Baseball: The Early Years|author=Harold Seymour|year=1960|page=350}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Lori Amber Roessner|title=Hero Crafting in ''Sporting Life'', an Early Baseball Journal|publisher=American Journalism|year=2009|url=http://www.cci.utk.edu/files/Roessner.AmericanJournalism.pdf}}</ref> By 1886, the publication had a circulation base of 40,000 subscribers.<ref name=BF/><ref>Roessner, Hero Crafting in Sporting Life, page 63. ("In 1886, when the Spink brothers established the Sporting News in St. Louis, Sporting Life had a circulation base of 40,000 subscribers.")</ref><ref name=SCD/> [[Henry Chadwick (writer)|Henry Chadwick]], sometimes called the "father of baseball", was a regular contributor to the ''Sporting Life''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Andrew Schiff|title=Henry Chadwick (SABR Baseball Biography Project)|publisher=Society for American Baseball Research|year=2008|url=http://sabr.org/bioproj/person/436e570c}}</ref>
The ''Sporting Life'' also published several early series of baseball cards that were offered to subscribers. The pre-World War I baseball cards published by the ''Sporting Life'' are among the most popular and scarce in the baseball collectible business. The popular series issued by ''Sporting Life'' include the M116 series issued in 1910 and 1911 and the W600 series issued from 1902 to 1911.<ref name=BF/><ref name=SCD>{{cite news|title=History of The Sporting Life and its Baseball Cards|publisher=Sports Collectors Daily|date=November 16, 2009|url=http://www.sportscollectorsdaily.com/history-of-the-sporting-life-and-its-baseball-cards/}}</ref>
Back issues of the ''Sporting Life'' are accessible in digital format through the [[LA84 Foundation]]'s digital sports library.<ref>{{cite web|title=LA84 Foundation Announces Digital Recreation of "The Sporting Life"|publisher=LA84 Foundation|url=http://www.la84foundation.org/10ap/NewsRelease05132008_frmst.htm|date=May 13, 2008}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://search.la84foundation.org/search?site=default_collection&client=default_frontend&output=xml_no_dtd&proxystylesheet=default_frontend&proxycustom=%3CHOME/%3E LA84 Foundation digital archives; includes ''Sporting Life'']
[[Category:National newspapers published in the United States]] [[Category:Sports newspapers]] [[Category:Publications established in 1883]]

{{about||the baseball maneuver|Stolen base|other uses|Stealing Home (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox film | | name = Stealing Home | image = Stealinghomeposter.jpg | caption = Theatrical poster | director = [[Steven Kampmann]]
William Porter (as Will Aldis) | writer = Steven Kampmann
William Porter (as Will Aldis) | producer = Chana Ben-Dov
[[Hank Moonjean]]
[[Thom Mount]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Mark Harmon]] * [[Jodie Foster]] * [[Blair Brown]] * [[Jonathan Silverman]] * [[Harold Ramis]] * [[William McNamara]] * [[John Shea]] }} | music = [[David Foster]] | cinematography = Bobby Byrne | editing = [[Antony Gibbs]] | distributor = [[Warner Bros.]] | released = August 26, 1988 | runtime = 98 min. | country = United States | language = English | awards = | budget = $14 million | gross = $7.46 million | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Stealing Home''''' is a 1988 American [[coming of age film| coming of age]] [[romantic drama film]], written and directed by [[Steven Kampmann]] and William Porter (billed as Will Aldis). The film stars [[Mark Harmon]], [[Jodie Foster]], [[Blair Brown]], [[Jonathan Silverman]], [[Harold Ramis]] and [[William McNamara]]. In the film; Billy Wyatt, a washed-up baseball player, is called back home to collect the ashes of his childhood sweetheart Katie Chandler, who had committed suicide. While doing so, he remembers the relationships he had with her and people he grew up with. ''Stealing Home'' was released theatrically on August 26, 1988 by [[Warner Bros.]] Upon release the film, was a critical and commercial failure, although David Foster's musical score garnered universal praise. Over the years it has attained a [[cult status]], praised for its pace, nostalgic feel and performances. The film holds a 93% rating on [[Google]] users aggregation while on review aggregator website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] it holds a rating of 20%. ==Plot== In the 1980s, Billy Wyatt ([[Mark Harmon]]) is a thirty-something washed up baseball player who now works as a high school groundskeeper, spending his days tending to the field and drinking. One afternoon he receives a phone call informing him that Katie Chandler ([[Jodie Foster]]), an old acquaintance, has died. The bulk of the film consists of extended flashbacks to the 1960s explaining Billy and Katie's relationship. Katie was a slightly older neighborhood girl who befriended Billy's mother, Ginny ([[Blair Brown]]), and who became his babysitter. Katie acts as a mentor to the young Billy, and, as he grows up, gives him advice on women and dating. As Billy ages he begins to develop feelings for Katie, though the rebellious and worldly wise Katie is interested in older men. Nevertheless, the two share a flirtatious relationship, and Katie comes to regard Billy as her closest friend and confidante. One summer in his late teens, Billy's father dies in a car accident, and Katie, Billy, and Ginny go on vacation to recover from the tragedy. While sharing a beach house, Katie encourages Ginny to have a one-night stand. An enraged Billy attacks the man whom she brings home, thinking that having sex with another man so soon is disrespectful to his father's memory. He and Katie argue, but later that night make up and sleep together. The next day, Katie tells Billy that she's leaving the country with a man she's been seeing, intending to live a life of adventure. In voice over narration, Billy recalls that this is the last time he ever saw Katie. In the present, Billy visits Katie's family. Her father tells Billy that Katie went through a series of failed and abusive relationships getting married and divorced 4 times and that she had seemed chronically unhappy for some time. Despite apparently rebounding from her most recent breakup, she unexpectedly committed suicide. Katie's father tells Billy that her suicide note requested that Billy be responsible for disposing of her ashes, and entrusts them to Billy. Billy reunites with his childhood friend Alan Appleby ([[Harold Ramis]]), and the two engage in a night of reminiscing and carousing with Katie's ashes while trying to decide what will be the most respectful way to dispose of them. Eventually, Billy recalls a memory of Katie telling him a story about watching an [[Atlantic City]] show in which a horse ran down a pier and jumped into the water, admiring the image of freedom it offered her. The next morning, Billy locates the same pier and scatters Katie's ashes there. Seeing a new sense of possibility in his own life, Billy reunites with a former girlfriend and joins a minor league baseball team; the film ends with Billy, his girlfriend, and Appleby celebrating after a game. ==Cast== *[[Mark Harmon]] as Billy Wyatt **[[William McNamara]] as young Billy Wyatt ** Thacher Goodwin as Billy Wyatt (age 10) *[[Jodie Foster]] as Katie Chandler *[[Harold Ramis]] as Alan Appleby **[[Jonathan Silverman]] as young Alan Appleby *[[Blair Brown]] as Ginny Wyatt *[[Richard Jenkins]] as Hank Chandler *[[John Shea]] as Sam Wyatt *[[Christine Jones (actress)|Christine Jones]] as Grace Chandler *[[Ted Ross]] as Bud Scott *[[Helen Hunt]] as Hope Wyatt *[[Beth Broderick]] as Leslie == Production == {{unreferenced section|date=August 2013}} The film plot is set in the [[Philadelphia]] area and the [[New Jersey]] shore. The filming occurred in many locations: *The house that Billy grows up in is located in [[Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania]], where exterior scenes were shot; *The interiors of Billy's childhood home were filmed in a house located in [[Springfield Township, Delaware County, Pennsylvania|Springfield, Pennsylvania]]; *The scenes in Bob's Diner were filmed at Ridge Avenue in Roxborough; *Alan Appleby's sporting goods store was located on Germantown Avenue in [[Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania]]; *Carlton Academy is actually [[Chestnut Hill Academy]]; *The opening scene and closing scene were shot at [[Fiscalini Field]] in [[San Bernardino, CA]]. The team he was shown playing for in the movie was the name of the actual team that played there at the time, The [[Inland Empire 66ers of San Bernardino|San Bernardino Spirit]]. *Camp Tecumseh, boys summer sports camp T-shirt is seen in the movie. ==Soundtrack== {{Track listing | extra_column=Artist | title1=Stealing Home | extra1=[[David Foster]] | length1=3:35 | title2=[[Sherry (song)|Sherry]] | extra2=[[The Four Seasons (band)|The Four Seasons]] | length2=2:30 | title3=And When She Danced (Love Theme From Stealing Home) | extra3=[[David Foster]] and [[Marilyn Martin]] | length3=3:50 | title4=[[Poison Ivy (song)|Poison Ivy]] | extra4=[[The Nylons]] | length4=3:21 | title5=[[All I Have To Do Is Dream]] | extra5=[[The Everly Brothers]] | length5=2:20 | title6=Home Movies | extra6=[[David Foster]] | length6=2:10 | title7=[[Great Balls Of Fire]] | extra7=[[Jerry Lee Lewis]] | length7=1:50 | title8=[[Baby It's You]] | extra8=[[The Shirelles]] | length8=2:38 | title9=Stealing Home/Reprise | extra9=[[David Foster]] | length9=5:08 | title10=[[Bo Diddley (song)|Bo Diddley]] | extra10=[[Bo Diddley]] | length10=2:19 | title11=Katie's Theme | extra11=[[David Foster]] | length11=1:30 }} ==Reception== The film received negative reviews around the time of its release. In her review for the ''[[New York Times]]'', [[Janet Maslin]] wrote, "The era is simply established as a dreamily idyllic past, thanks to sand dunes at twilight, waves that crash in the distance, shiny red convertibles without seat belts and a musical score that may make you want to weep, for all the wrong reasons".{{cite news | last = Maslin | first = Janet | coauthors = | title = Growing Up, and Into Baseball | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = [[New York Times]] | date = August 26, 1988 | url = https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?_r=1&res=940DE5D61E30F935A1575BC0A96E948260&oref=slogin | accessdate = 2008-04-16 }} In his one-star review for the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', [[Roger Ebert]] wrote, "I detested ''Stealing Home'' so much, from beginning to end, that I left the screening wondering if any movie could possibly be that bad".{{cite news | last = Ebert | first = Roger | coauthors = | title = ''Stealing Home'' | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = [[Chicago Sun-Times]] | date = August 26, 1988 | url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19880826/REVIEWS/808260303/1023 | accessdate = 2008-04-16 }} The movie currently holds a 22% Critics rating and a 78% Audience rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]]. When asked about the film in 2006, Mark Harmon said, "That was about a bunch of actors loving a script, going there and burning it on both ends for five weeks just to get it done. That was a fun one to make. I hear a lot about that role. People really found that movie on video."{{cite news | last = Rice | first = Lynette | coauthors = | title = Making His Mark | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | date = February 22, 2006 | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1162124,00.html | accessdate = 2008-04-16 }} ===''Summer of '42''=== Ever since the release of ''[[Summer of '42]]'', Warner Bros. has attempted to buy back the rights to the film, which they sold to author [[Herman Raucher]] in lieu of paying him for the script, under the belief that the film would not be financially successful. ''Stealing Home'' was greenlit shortly after Raucher denied their latest attempt to purchase the rights, leading to ''Summer'' star [[Jennifer O'Neill]]'s assertion that ''Stealing Home'' was "stolen" from ''Summer''. Regardless, she said that she enjoyed the movie and called it a "lovely film." [http://www.tv-now.com/intervus/oneill/index.html Jennifer O'Neill in 2002] ''tv-now.com'' Retrieved August 11, 2006 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060829114811/http://www.tv-now.com/intervus/oneill/index.html |date=August 29, 2006 }} Rita Kempley, in her review for the ''[[Washington Post]],'' also saw similarities with ''Summer'', describing the film as a "pale comedy-drama by mediocrities Steven Kampmann and Will Aldis. Admittedly a pastiche of their memories, the movie bespeaks the dust of '60s yearbooks and greeting card sentiment. Of course, that stuff can be touching (''[[Summer of '42]]'') or quirky (''[[Gregory's Girl]]''), but here only allergy sufferers will leave with soggy Kleenex."{{cite news | last = Kempley | first = Rita | title = ''Stealing Home'' | work = [[Washington Post]] | date = August 26, 1988 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/videos/stealinghomepg13kempley_a0c9f3.htm | accessdate = 2008-04-16 }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0096171}} *{{Amg movie|46754}} *{{rotten-tomatoes|stealing_home}} *{{mojo title|stealinghome}} [[Category:1988 films]] [[Category:1980s romantic drama films]] [[Category:1980s sports films]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:American coming-of-age films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films set in Philadelphia]] [[Category:Films set in New Jersey]] [[Category:Films shot in New Jersey]] [[Category:Films shot in Pennsylvania]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Villanova Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = | image = | fullname = | location = North Ithan Avenue
[[Villanova, Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] 19085 | coordinates = {{Coord|40|1|59|N|75|20|12|W|type:landmark_region:US-PA|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = October 8, 1927 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Villanova University]] | operator = [[Villanova University]] | surface = [[FieldTurf]]{{cite web|title=FieldTurf installed July 07, 2010 for Goodreau Field|url=http://www.fieldturf.com/installations/high-profile/villanova-university-goodreau-field/|publisher=Tarkett Sports|accessdate=17 October 2012}} | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | project_manager = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Villanova University|Villanova]] [[Villanova Wildcats|Wildcats]] ([[NCAA]])
[[Villanova Wildcats football|football]] (1927–81, 1985–present)
[[Villanova Wildcats men's lacrosse|men's lacrosse]] (1984–present)
women's lacrosse
field hockey
track & field
[[Philadelphia Charge]] ([[Women's United Soccer Association|WUSA]]) (2001–2003)
[[Philadelphia Barrage]] ([[Major League Lacrosse|MLL]]) (2004–2006) | suites = | seating_capacity = 12,500 | decks = | dimensions = | scoreboard = | publictransit= [[Stadium – Ithan Avenue (SEPTA station)|Stadium – Ithan Avenue]]: {{rail color box|system=SEPTA|line=NHSL}} }} '''Villanova Stadium''' is a 12,500 seat [[stadium]] located on the campus of [[Villanova University]] in [[Villanova, Pennsylvania]], USA.{{cite web|title=Villanova Stadium-Goodreau Field & Jumbo Elliott Track|url=http://www.villanova.com/facilities/nova-facilities-stadium.html|publisher=villanova.com|accessdate=1 August 2017}} ==History== Villanova Stadium was originally built in 1927 and dedicated on October 8, 1927.{{cite web|title=Big East Championships Sites Announced for 2017 and 2018|url=http://www.laxpower.com/laxnews/news.php?story=50039|publisher=laxpower.com|accessdate=1 August 2017}} The stadium plays host to a wide variety of events including serving as home to the [[Villanova Wildcats football]], [[field hockey]], [[lacrosse]], and [[track and field]] teams. Philadelphia area teams such as the [[Women's United Soccer Association|WUSA]]'s [[Philadelphia Charge]] and [[Major League Lacrosse]]'s [[Philadelphia Barrage]] have also used the stadium in the past or currently. In the 1960s, Monsignor Bonner High School, like Villanova an Augustinian school, used the field. The field and track at Villanova Stadium are known as "Goodreau Field" and "Jumbo Elliott Track," respectively. On May 7, 1930, the playing field at Villanova Stadium was dedicated to the memory of Leo J. Francis Goodreau, a Villanova football player who died due to injuries incurred in practice. On September 27, 1980, the running track was dedicated to Villanova's legendary [[track and field]] coach [[Jumbo Elliott (athletics)|James "Jumbo" Elliott]]. ===Renovations=== In Fall 1999, the stadium underwent a face-lift with the Stadium Renovation Project. Included in this project was a state of the art press box, in addition to housing an 80-person meeting room for all Villanova Athletic Department personnel to use. The former [[AstroTurf]] playing field was replaced during the spring of 2002 with a synthetic grass surface known as [[AstroPlay]]. In Fall 2009, the stadium received a new scoreboard along with a new playing surface. In 2016, a new football operations building, the [[Andy Talley|Andrew J. Talley]] Athletic Center, which also serves as the training room for the sports programs at the school, opened, named for the school's first head coach since the May 1984 reinstatement of the program until the end of 2016. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] {{Portal|Philadelphia}} == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.villanova.com/facilities/nova-facilities-stadium.html}} {{S-start}} {{Succession box| before = [[Columbus Crew Stadium]] | after = [[Nickerson Field]] | title = Host of [[Steinfeld Cup|Major League Lacrosse championship weekend]] | years = 2003 }} {{End}} {{Villanova Wildcats football navbox}} {{Villanova University}} {{Colonial Athletic Association football venue navbox}} {{Pennsylvania college football venues}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Delaware County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:College lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:College track and field venues in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Villanova Wildcats football]] [[Category:Lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1927]] [[Category:College field hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:1927 establishments in Pennsylvania]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox football club | clubname = Western Tigers FC | image = | fullname = Western Tigers Football Club | nickname = | founded = 1976 | ground = [[Georgetown Football Stadium]]
[[Georgetown, Guyana|Georgetown]], [[Guyana]] | capacity = 2,000 | chrtitle = | chairman = | mgrtitle = | manager = | league = [[GFA Association League]] | season = [[2013–14 GFF National Super League|2013–14]] | position = | current = | website = | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | pattern_sh1 = | pattern_so1 = | leftarm1 = FFFF00 | body1 = FFFF00 | rightarm1 = FFFF00 | shorts1 = FFFF00 | socks1 = ffff00 |pattern_la2 = |pattern_b2 = |pattern_ra2 = |pattern_sh2 = |pattern_so2 = |leftarm2 = ccffcc |body2 = ccffcc |rightarm2 = ccffcc |shorts2 = 000000 |socks2 = 000000 }} '''Western Tigers FC''' is a [[Guyana|Guyanese]] football club based in [[Georgetown, Guyana|Georgetown]], competing in the GFA League, an association league based in Georgetown which is the 2nd tier of Guyanese football. ==History== Founded in 1976 in the western region of the capital city of Georgetown, Western Tigers have won one league title in their history, in 1994–95.{{Cite web|url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesg/guyana95.html|title = Guyana 1995|date = 12 September 2013|accessdate = 6 February 2015|website = RSSSF|publisher = RSSSF.com|last = Stokkermans |first = Karel}} Western Tigers participated internationally in the [[CONCACAF Cup Winners Cup|1995 CONCACAF Cup Winners Cup]], losing to [[CRKSV Jong Colombia|Jong Colombia]] of the [[Netherland Antilles]] 6–4 on aggregate.{{Cite web|url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesc/cacups95.html|title = Central American Club Competitions 1995|date = 12 September 2013|accessdate = 6 February 2015|website = RSSSF|publisher = RSSSF.com|last = Stokkermans |first = Karel}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Guyana National Football League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Guyana]] [[Category:1976 establishments in Guyana]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1976]] {{Guyana-sport-stub}} {{Caribbean-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox sports team | team = ZPC Het Ravijn | color1 = | color2 = | logo = ZPC Het Ravijn logo.jpg | pixels = | founded = 1961 | league = [[Dutch Women's Water Polo Championship|Dutch Championship]] | history = | arena = [[Zwemsportzorgcentrum het Ravijn|ZSZC Het Ravijn]] | ballpark = | stadium = | city = [[Nijverdal]] | colors = {{color box|red}} {{color box|white}} | colours = | owner = | president = | coach = | manager = | championships = '''Women''':
4 Dutch Championships
8 Dutch Cups
'''Men''':
1 Dutch Cup | titles = | cheerleaders = | dancers = | mascot = | broadcasters = | media = | website = http://www.zpc-hetravijn.nl/ }} '''Zwem en Polo Club Het Ravijn''' is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[water sports]] from [[Nijverdal]] club founded in 1961. It is best known for its women's [[water polo]] team, which has won four [[Dutch Women's Water Polo Championship|national championships]] since 2000. It reached the final of the [[Women's LEN Trophy]] in 2006 and 2011, but it lost them against [[Budapesti Honvéd SE (men's water polo)|Budapest Honvéd]] and [[Pro Recco|Rapallo]] respectively.[http://www.rtvoost.nl/nieuws/default.aspx?nid=124533 Het Ravijn loses the LEN Trophy final]. RTV Oost, 20 April 2011 ==Titles== * '''Men's water polo''' ** '''[[Dutch Water Polo Cup|Dutch Cup]] (1)''' *** 1995 * '''Women's water polo''' ** '''[[Dutch Women's Water Polo Championship|Dutch Championship]] (5)''' *** 2000, 2003, 2008, 2012, 2013 ** '''[[Dutch Women's Water Polo Cup|Dutch Cup]] (8)''' *** 1995, 1996, 1997, 1999, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2010 ==Former internationals== [[Hellen Boering]], [[Bert Brinkman]], [[Rianne Guichelaar]], [[Niels van der Kolk]], [[Karin Kuipers]], [[Meike de Nooy]], [[Carla Quint]], [[Yasemin Smit]], [[Wyco de Vries]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Het Ravijn}} [[Category:Water polo clubs in the Netherlands]] [[Category:LEN Women's Champions' Cup clubs]] [[Category:Sports clubs established in 1961]] [[Category:Sport in Overijssel|ZPC Het Ravijn]] [[Category:Hellendoorn|ZPC Het Ravijn]] [[Category:1961 establishments in the Netherlands]] {{Netherlands-sport-stub}} {{water-sports-stub}}
